handNote.p: Main scribe of the manuscript. A square Anglo-Saxon miniscule, described by Ker as 'handsome'.

This is hand of the main Rochester reviser. Ker describes the hand as 'sprawling, but firm and well-marked', with e slightly ascending and open at the top. It should be noted that Ker's palaeographical description on p. 367 erroneously states that this hand is responsible for a homily on Paulinus in 'art. 76', but in fact that added Paulinus homily is Ker's art. 75. Digipal terms this hand the 'Principal Corrector'.

A compact, somewhat squareish emending hand, baseline tending to slant downwards to the right. Frequent long s, dotted y; uses triple punctus insertions. e often open at the top. Responsible for a large proportion of the vel-insertions, which are indicated with the usual crossed 'l'.
Emending hand that uses double-point insertion marks, cf. 114r, 118r.
Emending hand with wider ductus, rounder in aspect.
